subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: get your news in QS!
msgSnippet: ... Yes, I am using the CMU dictionary. I never thought of using the accent marks to determine the correct vowels. The main drawback (as others have pointed
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn wrote:

> If you are using the CMU dictionary, the entries include stress marks
> next to the phonetics (a number 0, 1 or 2). In particular 0 means no
> stress. If you felt like it, this could be used to approximate the
> rules for terminal unstressed "y" "al" "el" "le" "ier" "ey "ie" etc if
> desired (things explicitly needed in senior anyway). Of course such
> refinements are insignificant compared with the idea and
> implementation of the live-ish QS conversion in the first place.

Yes, I am using the CMU dictionary. I never thought of using the accent
marks to determine the correct vowels. The main drawback (as others have
pointed out) is that the dictionary does not use "On" at all. It uses
"Ah" for every vowel where either one might be used. So father is
spelled with "Ah" as is pot. I found other mistakes as well. I used this
dictionary to transliterate the 2000 most common words in English, and
when I checked the result, I found so many mistakes that, after I
corrected the mistakes in my 2000 word list, to use this 2000 word list
as the main dictionary. But for this project, where I can't check the
transliteration every time, I reverted back to the huge word base.


>
> Not that I've tried it, but to approximate this, maybe any capital
> letter not preceded but terminal punctuation (period, question mark
> etc) and not starting a block of text can be assumed to be a name.

Yes, this technique would work better. My method right now is more
simple. Another trick is to find phrases like "President Bush."

Paul
